sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: New month, new wallpapers! In this post, you’ll find unique and inspiring wallpapers for August 2021. Created with love by the community for the community, they come in versions with and without a calendar for the month.
articles.title: Good Vibes In August (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: Having an e-commerce store is crucial for any store owner as more and more customers are turning to online shopping. In this tutorial, we shall go through how to create an e-commerce site with Angular 11. The site will use the Commerce Layer as a headless e-commerce API and use Paypal to process payments.
articles.title: How To Build An E-Commerce Site With Angular 11, Commerce Layer And Paypal

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Elad Shechter)
articles.description: What are absolute units? What are the differences between relative and absolute units, and how do we create accurate sizes on the web? In this article, Elad Shechter explains why CSS absolute units aren’t so absolute.
articles.title: There Is No Such Thing As A CSS Absolute Unit

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kitty Giraudel)
articles.description: Dialogs are everywhere in modern interface design (for good or for bad), and yet many of them are not accessible to assistive technologies. In this article, we will dig into how to create a short script to create accessible dialogs.
articles.title: Creating An Accessible Dialog From Scratch

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alexander Dubovoy)
articles.description: Next.js has strong opinions about how to organize JavaScript but not CSS. How can we develop patterns that encourage best CSS practices while also following the framework’s logic? The answer is surprisingly simple — to write well-structured CSS that balances global and local styling concerns.
articles.title: Global vs. Local Styling In Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Scanlon)
articles.description: Gatsby recently announced the launch of “functions”. In this article, Paul Scanlon explains how to get the current location of the International Space Station (ISS) as it orbits the Earth in real-time using [Gatsby Functions](https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/reference/functions/) and then display it on a 3D interactive globe using [React Three Fibre](https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber).
articles.title: Gatsby Serverless Functions And The International Space Station

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Many web design agencies consider it a badge of honor that they win work exclusively through word-of-mouth recommendations. In this article, Paul Boag explains why that is entirely the wrong attitude and what to do about it.
articles.title: A Guide To Attracting Clients To Your Agency

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Matthew Talebi)
articles.description: Are you running a business and have too many things going on at once? Meetings, bugs, customer feedback, new clients in addition to your already tight deadlines? Let’s face it, time management is hard, and it becomes even more difficult in the trying times we are in.
articles.title: Adding Time To Your Schedule As A Professional

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Do you need a little inspiration boost? We’ve collected some useful color tools and resources that we’ve discovered lately — to help you get the most out of your creativity. We’ve also just recently covered [CSS auditing tools](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-auditing-tools/), [CSS generators](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-generators/), [accessible front-end components](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/complete-guide-accessible-front-end-components/), [front-end boilerplates](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/06/useful-frontend-boilerplates-starter-kits/) and [VS code extensions](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/05/useful-vs-code-extensions-web-developers/) — you might find them useful, too.
articles.title: Color Tools And Resources

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alba Silvente)
articles.description: In this article, we will look at when it makes sense to migrate from a monolithic project to a headless setup and the benefits that come with it. In addition to a step-by-step guide on how to migrate WordPress to Storyblok Headless CMS, the problems that will arise during the process and how to deal with them.
articles.title: How To Migrate From WordPress To A Headless CMS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Colby Fayock)
articles.description: By adding visual elements to your tests, you can gain more options to add meaningful ways in maintaining a high level of quality for your app. Colby Fayock explains how.
articles.title: Maintaining End-To-End Quality With Visual Testing

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Marcus Herrmann)
articles.description: Web app accessibility appears difficult because it seems that there is little information on the subject available online. Let’s take a closer look at the accessible use of framework features, concrete Vue.js traits, as well as community initiatives and vetted patterns.
articles.title: Three Insights I Gained While Researching Vue.js Accessibility

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cassidy Williams)
articles.description: There are two strategies for incrementally building websites that are growing in popularity: Incremental Static Regeneration and Distributed Persistent Rendering. What’s the difference? Let’s figure it out.
articles.title: ISR vs DPR: Big Words, Quick Explanation

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: In this article, you’ll get to see some pretty groundbreaking things you can achieve with modern JavaScript grids and discover new ways to augment a data grid to make it engaging, responsive, and accessible. All this will be illustrated using Kendo UI Data Grids and their features.
articles.title: You Can Do That With A JavaScript Data Grid?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Too often dealing with filters can be frustrating. Let’s get them right. That means never freeze the UI on a single input, provide text input fallback and never auto-scroll users on a single input. Here’s why.
articles.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Broken Filters

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Michelle Barker)
articles.description: In JavaScript, attaching an event listener to constantly fire a callback on scroll can be performance-intensive. But there is a better way with Intersection Observer.
articles.title: Building A Dynamic Header With Intersection Observer

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Facundo Giuliani)
articles.description: In this article, we’re taking a closer look at different approaches and strategies on how we can migrate a web application that uses jQuery framework, and start using one of the coolest React frameworks in the market: Next.js.
articles.title: How To Migrate From jQuery To Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: CSS refactoring is not an easy task — it needs to be done in a way that doesn't create problems. First we need to analyze the existing codebase, audit CSS codebase health, discover weaknesses, agree on the approach, and convince management to invest time and resources into the process.
articles.title: Refactoring CSS: Introduction (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Todd Libby)
articles.description: Accessibility is often overlooked or bolted on to the end of a project. Let’s figure out how to implement and advocate for accessibility from the inception of a project to the release or handoff and beyond.
articles.title: Making A Strong Case For Accessibility

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Uma Victor)
articles.description: Even though Vue.js claims to have an approachable minimalist framework that can be incrementally adaptable, it can be a little bit overwhelming when starting as a Vue.js newbie. In this article, we’re looking at ways to make writing Vue.js a breeze.
articles.title: Tools And Practices To Speed Up The Vue.js Development Process

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Emiliano Cicero)
articles.description: Interactive Components in Figma allows designers to create a component with states (hover, active, clicked, focus) and make it interactive so that every copy of the component will inherit those same interactions by default. Let’s explore how it can reduce the time and effort needed to create interactions for your mock-ups.
articles.title: An Introduction To Figma Interactive Components

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Emmanuel Tissera)
articles.description: There is an array of Headless CMSes out there. In this article, we delve into headless CMS features to satisfy your content editors, marketers and yourself as a developer. For the experience headless practitioner, this could be a checklist to see what’s new out there. For those starting out on their headless journey, this could be a guide on what to look for.
articles.title: How To Choose A Headless CMS

articles.title: Excel Text Function – How to Convert a Number to Text Format

articles.title: Google Docs Voice Typing – How to Use Speech-to-Text in a Google Doc

articles.title: Not Equal Sign – How to Type the Does Not Equal Symbol

articles.author: Mariam Reba Alexander
articles.description:
After discussing about Cross Site Scripting Attacks (XSS) in the previous posts, I am going to explain now about another type of attack Cross-site Request Forgery Attack (CSRF or XSRF), sometimes pronounced as "sea-surf". It has number of other names such as Session Riding, Cross-Site Reference Forgery, Hostile Linking and One-click attack.
CSRF is a more common vulnerability in websites, and the attack sometimes goes unnoticed by the victim. The after effects can be damaging as it happens within an authenticated session, and can perform user actions without the user's knowledge. For example, change password of user, one-click purchase on Amazon, post obscene content in the users social platform, transfer funds and so on.
The attacker may send a link via email or chat and trick the users o…
articles.title: Cross-site Request Forgery Attacks (CSRF): What a frontend developer should know

articles.author: Daniel Kneipp
articles.description:
If you have used provisioned instances on AWS before, you know that the default metrics monitored are kind of limited. You only have access to CPU utilization, network transfer rates and disk reads/writes. By default, you don't have the monitoring of some basic information, like RAM and filesystem usage (which ca be a very valuable information to prevent an instance malfunction due to lack of resources).
In case of GPU-accelerated applications (like Machine Learning apps), this problem goes even further, since you also don't have any access to GPU metrics, which is critical to guarantee the reliability of the system (e.g. the total GPU memory consumption can lead to the crash of any application running on the GPU).
I've created a project (available here) showing how we can create an AMI wi…
articles.title: Instrumenting AMIs for GPU monitoring on CloudWatch

articles.title: JavaScript: Concept of  Promise

articles.author: shubham rathod
articles.description:
Designing a website starts with defining the role the website is meant to serve, or its purpose.
You’re guessing right – there are different types of websites that are used for different purposes. The three most popular ones are: landing pages, one-pages and classic websites. Obviously, there are also large sites (portals and the like), but that’s a completely different topic.
You need to know what purpose your website is meant to have. That way the website you’re designing will be understandable to the users.
If you run a business of some sort, the user needs to know right from the start what you have to offer.
For example – you own a car repair garage. The user needs to know they have entered a repair garage’s website and that they can use specific services.
The purpose of such website i…
articles.title: Website design – how to start?

articles.author: Bek Brace
articles.description:
GraphQL is an abbreviation for Graph Query Language.
So, to make things clearer , in traditional REST API, you consume apis using REST and we have done that so many times with Flask, Django and FastAPI by sending different HTTP request methods like GET, POST, PUT , and DELETE to the API using path or URLS 
Now the problem with HTTP requests is that when the request is received from the front-end user, 




The other problem is the opposite, which means that you might want to fetch multiple data or get multiple resources simultaneously, and this is not possible, because there is no enough data per HTTP request.  
And there comes the power of GraphQL
The way this works is by start defining  a schema with objects using type keyword, and a type can have multiple fields like an id, and if you w…
articles.title: GraphQL and FastAPI Combination

articles.author: Jean-Michel Fayard 🇫🇷🇩🇪🇬🇧🇪🇸🇨🇴
articles.description:
Hi, I'm Jean-Michel, a Kotlin fan like you! At the end of each month, I'll be showcasing some great posts, projects and insights from the Kotlin community, right here on DEV.to.
#kotlin Follow

      
Among the popular articles of the months, here are those I've read and can recommend:
How to get started with Android App Development? Rohit Kumar provides beginners with a roadmap of what to learn. Spoiler alert: there is a lot!
What to Learn to get started with Android App Development?
ROHIT KUMAR ・ Jul 12 ・ 6 min read
#beginners
        #android
        #kotlin
        #java
      
Next, there is my article who encourages you to write command-line tools to automate your workflow, but to make sure you use your favorite programming language, not Bash! Be sure to check my starter project for CLI tools in Kotlin multiplatform.
How to Write a Command-Line Tool with Kotlin Multiplatform
Jean-Michel Fayard 🇫🇷🇩🇪🇬🇧🇪🇸🇨🇴 ・ Jul 13 ・ 6 min read
#kotlin
        #productivity
        #showdev
      
Lists are the bread and butter of programming with Kotlin. Do you think you master them? Sebastian Aigner comes back with an article and YouTube episode to explore what you may not know yet.
Exploring Kotlin Lists in 2021
Sebastian Aigner for Kotlin ・ Jul 8 ・ 12 min read
#kotlin
        #programming
        #android
        #productivity
      
Finally, Christy Jacob presents what's new in Appwrite, an ambitious open-source alternative to Firebase in active development. That includes a Kotlin SDK both for Android and for server-side.
Announcing Appwrite 0.9: The open source Firebase alternative 
Christy Jacob for Appwrite ・ Jul 7 ・ 5 min read
#flutter
        #android
        #kotlin
        #opensource
      
That's all for this month!
Remember to follow the Kotlin tag
#kotlin Follow

      
If you want to contact me, there is a standing invitation at https://jmfayard.dev/contact/.
articles.title: Kotlin monthly wrap-up: July 2021

articles.author: Abba Vincent Ihechikara
articles.description: Modules in JavaScript have been around for quite a while but were originally implemented in libraries. An example would be how we can import a React component and make use of it in different components without the need to rewrite the function or class from scratch. Modules help us to avoid reinventing the wheel by writing the same logic twice. It also aids in the separation of concerns; you can have a separate module just for adding numbers or another for fetching data from an API. This way, you know exactly where everything belongs. Imagine if all of Google’s code was in one single file and every time the team had to fix something in the search bar, they had to scroll through a billion lines of code just to get to that particular section, wouldn’t that be hectic? Modules help us separate …
articles.title: ES6 Modules and Application

articles.author: Tomasz Wegrzanowski
articles.description:
This episode was created in collaboration with the amazing Amanda Cavallaro. Over the next episodes we'll be working on a simple Terminal app. Modern terminals are very complex but a very minimal one just needs: a way to input commands run those commands show the output And in this episode, we'll ignore the pesky "run commands" part, and just start with styling. Let's just think how we're going to represent the terminal. We need some input and some history. Episode 8 - Terminal App

Very amazing terminal app

$
articles.title: Electron Adventures: Episode 8: Terminal App Styling

articles.author: Mansoor Ahmed
articles.description:
Introduction
Showing images
Description
Python Imaging Library (PIL)
How to install Pillow?
Next, it’s open:
$ pip install Pillow
from PIL import Image, ImageFilter
im = Image.open( 'image.jpg' )
im.show()
im_sharp = im.filter( ImageFilter.SHARPEN )
im_sharp.save( 'image_sharpened.jpg', 'JPEG' )
r,g,b = im_sharp.split()
exif_data = im._getexif()
exif_data
How to install Open Source Computer Vision?
NumPy may be downloaded from the Python Package Index(PyPI):
$ pip install numpy
import cv2
img = cv2.imread('testimg.jpg')
cv2.imshow('image',img)
cv2.waitKey(0)
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
gray = cv2.cvtColor(img, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
cv2.imwrite('graytest.jpg',gray)
NumPy
SciPy
Functions for linear and non-linear filtering,
Even beginning programmers may write machine vision tests
https://www.technologiesinindustry4.com/2021/07/python-image-handling-libraries.html
articles.title: Python Image Handling Libraries

articles.author: Shivam Rohilla
articles.description:
Hello guys, in this post I'll tell you about how I double my salary in a year.
I started my career as a web designer, I learned HTML, CSS, Js and PHP and MySQL, I my got my first job as a web designer on January 2020, they gave me only 9k/mo, my first salary was 9k INR only, and I travelled daily for 3 hours and after job I took the metro and come to home and rest for 5-10 mints and go to gym, because gym is very important. It helps me to reduce my stress and all anger, and after 3 months Corona virus is came and everyone knows that how dangerous it is, and in lockdown I applied for a new job and I got a job in lockdown as a web designer and that company gave me 15k/MO INR, then I started learning Python from YouTube, I learned python in 4months and I practice python at full night's and after python I decided to learn Django framework from YouTube and I learned Django in 2 months, and I practiced this for 2 months, and after that I applied for a new job and in December 2020 a company hired me in 18k/mo INR, and after this, but that company was fraud, and after this company I got job offer as a Django Developer and that company hired me in 25k/Mo, I worked there only for one month, because my dad was passed away because of Corona, I ask them for money, for my father but they denied and I leave that company, and in that company there's no humanity they are very cruel, but after 2 weeks, I cleared a interview in an International company, and this company is a game changer for my career, they hired me as a Software Engineer and my package is 4.5 Lacs per annum, 32k/Mo. I just want to say one thing that always believe in God, God is everything ❤️.
Always trying, do work hard
and the most important thing be positive.
articles.title: How I double my salary package in a year, Web designer to Python Developer.

articles.author: Mansoor Ahmed
articles.description:
Introduction
The libraries offer a middle layer too: Apollo Engine, which may be a GraphQL gateway. Basically, there’s a motive Apollo is one of the leading popular choices for using GraphQL in JavaScript applications. Apollo GraphQL may be a platform that lets us do API calls using GraphQL. It is modern thanks to fetching data because it deals with asynchronous fetching and only fetches the info we actually need. So, there won’t be needless data that takes up excessive space and our application will load faster.
Description
Apollo’s Ecosystem
Apollo’s Ecosystem
The Company and Community behind Apollo
Who is using Apollo?
Airbnb [1] [2]
Apollo Libraries
Apollo is additionally offering exchangeable libraries which may be seen within the Apollo Client Cache. The Apollo Client that one isn’t prejudiced toward its cache, where the info is kept, by way of any cache advertised by Apollo or its community works. There are already caches available which will be wont to setup a Apollo Client instance.
Importance of Apollo GraphQL
Apollo’s Features
Interoperability with other Frameworks
Apollo is additionally library agnostic on the server-side, and it offers several solutions to attach with Node.js libraries. Apollo Server for Express.js is one of the leading standard choices among developers and corporations, and there are other solutions for Koa and Hapi on Node.js for Apollo Server also.
Modern Data Handling with Apollo
Appropriate Development Experience
